newsitem.title: CANADA: Videotron shares rise on U.K. asset sale.
newsitem.headline: Videotron shares rise on U.K. asset sale.

text.p: Shares of Groupe Videotron Ltee rose C$1 on the Toronto Stock Exchange by late Tuesday afternoon after the company announced it was selling its 56 percent interest in Videotron Holdings Plc.
If the transaction is completed as expected, Videotron will recoup US$600 million (C$825 million), or US$19.75 for each American Depository Share (ADS) of Videotron Holdings.
The sale price was in the mid-range of the US$17 to US$23 analysts had expected in February when Videotron put Videotron Holdings, which holds its U.K. cable assets, up for sale.

But the final transaction price was about C$125 million higher than financial markets had been expecting in recent days. With 107 million Groupe Videotron shares outstanding, that price differential translates into about C$1 a share, which accounts for the rise in the company's share price, said Simon Lussier, analyst at Sprott Securities.
"The price is right. It's higher than the street expected and the company will invest the money in North America," Lussier said.
But analyst Ben Dube of Credifinance Securities said he was surprised Videotron's shares did not jump further.
The offer of $19.75 for each ADS is all-cash, rather that the cash-and-share offer expected earlier.
"It's a good deal for Videotron. I'm surprised that the stock did not go higher," Dube said.

American Depository Shares of Bell Cablemedia Plc, which is to acquire Videotron Holdings as the first step in the creation of a new U.K. telephony concern led by Cable and Wireless Plc, rose $1 to $15-5/8 on Nasdaq.
Bell Cablemedia is owned by Bell Canada International, a unit of BCE Inc, Canada's largest telecommunications company. Shares of BCE rose C$0.55 on Tuesday to C$59.30.
